title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" amends the Securities Act of 1933 to increase the exemption threshold from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000 and excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to deem certain issuers as investment companies for specific limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify issuers with securities owned exclusively by qualified purchasers as investment companies for specific limitations on securities transactions with registered investment companies. SEC. 4. DEFINITION OF QUALIFIED PURCHASER. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "Qualified purchaser" as a natural person with at least $10,000,000 in securities, a person with at least $100,000,000 in securities for their own or others' accounts, or a person determined by the Commission to not need certain protections. The Commission may determine that certain individuals with a higher level of financial sophistication and substantial assets do not need the protections of the Investment Company Act of 1940. The Commission can also establish rules for these individuals as deemed necessary for the public interest and investor protection. SEC. 5 of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to redefine investment securities. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph stating that companies not issuing redeemable securities and regulated by the state can engage in economic development activities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow companies regulated by the state to engage in economic development activities, with certain conditions such as holding at least 80 percent of securities by residents or those with a substantial business presence in the state, selling securities only to accredited investors, and not purchasing any security. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows state-regulated companies to engage in economic development activities under certain conditions, including holding securities by residents or those with a substantial business presence in the state, selling only to accredited investors, and not purchasing certain securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows state-regulated companies to engage in economic development activities by investing 65 percent of their assets in specified securities or comparable ones. Companies must file a notification with the Commission to rely on this exemption. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows state-regulated companies to invest in specified securities. Companies meeting the requirements can rely on this exemption by filing a notification with the Commission. The exemption may be subject to additional terms and conditions determined by the Commission. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 by changing the minimum amount for closed-end investment company exemption to $10,000,000. SEC. 8 revises the definition of eligible portfolio company by setting limits on total assets and capital. SEC. 9 updates the definition of a business development company. SEC. 9 updates the definition of a business development company by allowing exceptions for providing managerial assistance to certain companies. SEC. 10 amends rules for business development companies to acquire assets from various sources as regulated by the Commission. SEC. 11 amends the capital structure of business development companies. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The amendment allows for a 200 percent asset coverage requirement, with a provision for a minimum of 110 percent coverage under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing indebtedness unless provisions are made to restrict dividend declarations or other distributions on capital stock. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. Business development companies are prohibited from issuing senior securities representing indebtedness unless provisions are made to restrict dividend declarations or other distributions on capital stock. It shall be unlawful for any business development company to declare dividends or distributions on capital stock unless certain asset coverage requirements are met. Business development companies must meet asset coverage requirements to issue senior securities, prohibiting dividend declarations or distributions on capital stock unless certain conditions are met. Business development companies must meet asset coverage requirements to issue senior securities. Dividend declarations or distributions on capital stock prohibited unless specific conditions are met, including compliance with regulated investment company status under the Internal Revenue Code. Business development companies can issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities without accompanying securities if certain conditions are met and approved by shareholders or partners. Business development companies can issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities if authorized by shareholders or partners and approved by the required majority of directors or general partners. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 to include "and capital structure" after "portfolio".
